awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Advancing turbidity currents: moving sources, polydispersity and aggregation
awd_abstract_narration:
Gravity currents are mostly horizontal flows that are driven by density variations in a fluid or by density differences between two fluids. They play a central role in the transport of sediment in lakes, rivers, and oceans, and they are also important in emerging and potentially transformative technologies such as deep-sea mining and geoengineering. Despite a rich history of research on gravity currents, some fundamental scenarios have yet to be explored or remain substantially unresolved. This collaborative project will integrate analytical modeling, numerical simulation and laboratory experimentation with a unique field experimental data set to advance understanding of particle-laden gravity currents. This project has potential for transformative impacts by informing environmental regulations for such emerging industries as deep-sea mining. Deep-sea mining is expected to re-suspend large volumes of sediment in the pristine abyssal ocean environment, and the knowledge and models developed through this project will provide the toolbox needed to assess the evolution of these sediment plumes.  The project will provide training for university students at all academic levels and for high-school students who will participate in the project through established programs at MIT and UCSB.  

The project is divided into three interconnected topics. The first concerns the evolution of gravity and particle-driven currents released from a moving source. The goals are to understand how the ratio of source speed to buoyancy velocity influences the dynamics of the current, investigate the role of background current, and develop empirical models that predict transport processes. The second point of focus is to quantify sediment detrainment from polydisperse particle-driven currents and determine its sensitivity to the particle size and velocity distribution through concurrent laboratory experiments and numerical simulations. Empirical models of polydisperse particle-driven currents will be extended to include entrainment and detrainment and incorporated into the moving source gravity current model. Finally, the role of flocculation and aggregation of particles on the propagation of polydisperse particle-driven currents will be experimentally investigated by systematically varying the sediment’s history, with the goal of developing macroscale numerical models for flocculation and integrating the findings into the moving source model.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Turbidity currents are among the largest sediment transport processes on Earth. They are the primary mechanism by which sediment is transported from the coastal to the deep ocean, and hence they play a crucial role in the global sediment cycle. A single turbidity current can transport many cubic kilometers of sediment over distances in excess of 1,000 kilometers. Being able to predict the dynamics of such currents is essential for hydrocarbon exploration, and for the protection of submarine infrastructure such as telecommunication cables and oil and gas pipelines.

Turbidity currents often occur unexpectedly in remote locations and they can be highly destructive, so that they are difficult to explore via field studies. Hence we aim to obtain insight into the dynamics and evolution of turbidity currents propagating over erodible sediment beds via particle resolved, large-scale direct numerical simulations. The sediment in turbidity currents has a wide range of grain sizes, ranging from mud with O(10μm) to sand of O(1mm) and larger. To address this multiscale nature of turbidity currents, we employ a two-level modeling approach in which the much larger sand grains that constitute the particle bed are resolved with the immersed boundary method, while the finer suspended sediment is treated using an Eulerian framework. As part of the NSF funded research project, we conduct four different types of simulations for four classes of substrate and sediment mobility: non-erodible and non-porous smooth wall, fixed rough and porous sediment bed, bed-load transport, and suspended-load sediment transport. The front location and velocity of the current demonstrate that the presence of the sediment bed retards the current relative to the smooth wall case. Our simulations have explored and quantified the effects of erosion, porosity, and particle-turbulence coupling on the velocity, turbulent kinetic energy and runout length of turbidity currents, those providing enhanced predictive tools for their dynamics.
